reviews.text: One member of staff helped me out today. There are no lifts and I needed the underground, a tall mixed race guy who worked there came over and helped me take my baby boy in his buggy down the escalator, he knew there was about 10 steps after, so he walked with me, helped me carry the buggy down the stairs and made sure I got the platform ok. It's people like this, that make the world a better place. He didn't have to help me at all, but he did.

Lovely old fashioned English station - famous for The Beatles' Hard Day's Night film - you'd never think this was a central London terminus...took a pleasant journey up into the Chiltern Hills & out to Aylesbury from here...helpful train driver pointed me in the right direction for my train...& there's an M&S Food...
Nice and tidy station. Friendly staff, lots of shops. Did you know you can buy your tickets up to 5 times cheaper if you buy on-line?

Stinks of diesel fumes, which means it has high concentration of air pollution particles and is not the healthiest of stations. I'm surprised the line hasn't been electrified yet and that Chiltern Railways are not making any visible effort to reduce emissions and local air pollution. Of course, travelling by train is overall better than travelling by car, but certainly there is a lot to be desired here. 
Otherwise, the station has very fast and convenient links and is pretty.

Great station except for one thing:  they do not announce the platform the train is leaving from until very shortly before it is due to depart...  Then everyone has to run to the platform and there is a terrible scrum.  If you are in the least bit disabled, or have heavy luggage, this is very unpleasant.  Why can't they announce the platform well in advance?  On European trains, the platform is even printed on the ticket, so you can go there calmly and in good time.
